resources.string: Please tap the \'new password\' button to start entering die rolls.
Unable to get random numbers from random.org.
Please roll %1$d six-sided dice (all at once or in batches) and tap the results on the dice images below.
A Diceware password of the selected length can resist a brute force attack from a well-funded adversary (such as the NSA circa 2013) for:
Copying passwords to the clipboard is insecure. Other apps may monitor the clipboard and capture its contents. Proceed with caution.
Do not show this warning again
Password generation failed. Please contact Apta Systems.

From Wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diceware): \'Diceware is a method for creating passphrases, passwords, and other cryptographic variables using an ordinary die from a pair of dice as a hardware random number generator. For each word in the passphrase, five rolls of the dice are required. The numbers from 1 to 6 that come up in the rolls are assembled as a five-digit number, e.g. 43146. That number is then used to look up a word in a word list.\'
Paraphrased from the Diceware Passphrase Home Page (http://world.std.com/~reinhold/diceware.html): Diceware is easy to learn and use, very secure, transparent, prescriptive, and free.
What is a brute force attack?

From Wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brute-force_attack): \'In cryptography, a brute-force attack, or exhaustive key search, is a cryptanalytic attack that can, in theory, be used against any encrypted data ... It consists of systematically checking all possible keys or passwords until the correct one is found. In the worst case, this would involve traversing the entire search space.
A millennium is 1,000 years. A century is 100 years.
How are the attack times estimated?
First, an estimate of the number of guesses that can be made per second must be produced. Edward Snowden told the world in 2013 that the NSA is capable of making one trillion guesses per second.

Second, the number of possible passwords must be calculated. This is done by taking the number of words in the word list (there are 7,776 in the Reinhold and EFF (long) lists) and raising it to the power of the number of words in the password (the password length).
Finally, we divide the number of possible passwords by the guess rate and then divide that number by two to determine the average number of seconds until the brute force attack is successful.

For example, a five-word Diceware password (EFF (long)/Reinhold) will resist a brute force attack for 14 million seconds on average (just over 164 days): 7,776^5 / 1,000,000,000,000 / 2 = 14,215,144.015

A password that can survive a brute force attack for over three millennia (password length of six words) now may not be able to do so in several years. If the guessing speed increases by several orders of magnitude, that same password may only survive a brute force attack for three years.

When generating a passphrase you may select one of four word lists. The Reinhold list is the original word list by Arnold Reinhold, first published in 1995. This list contains 7,776 words, equal to the number of possible ordered rolls of five six-sided dice.

The Electronic Frontier Foundation has published three word lists. The EFF (long) list is a list of 7,776 words that offers equivalent security to the Reinhold list, but some changes have been made to the words resulting in passphrases that should be easier to type and remember.

The EFF (short) list includes the 1,296 most memorable and distinct words (four dice instead of five) in the hope that a smaller word list might offer a usability improvement for longer passphrases. Passphrases generated with this list will be weaker than the long list on a per-word basis, so in order to achieve similar security, longer passphrases must be used.

The EFF (short, edit distance of 3 apart) list is similar to the EFF (short) list but each word has a unique three-character prefix. This means that future software could auto-complete words in the passphrase after the user has typed the first three characters. Also, all words are an edit distance (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edit_distance) of at least three apart. This means that future software could correct any single typo in the user\'s passphrase.

This application is open source. That means that anybody can go look at the source code, and if they want to, use the source code in their own projects. This also means that one can look at the code and see exactly what the application is doing and verify that it isn\'t (for example) sending the passwords it generates back to me, or the NSA, or anywhere. I don\'t trust any security/privacy related application that isn\'t open source, and you shouldn\'t either.

Please note that the source code has not been audited by an independent third party. If you or your organisation are interested in performing an audit, please contact me, my email address may be found at the bottom of this page.

My name is Jeff Isaak. My background is software development. I am passionate about online security and privacy, personal finance, and garlic. I want to help people reclaim their privacy through clever software. My email address is jisaak@aptasystems.com.

Credit is due to Arnold Reinhold for the concept of Diceware and the original wordlist, the EFF for the alternative wordlists, and the worldwide volunteers who translate the wordlist. Thanks also to Julio Díaz for the EFF wordlist pull request.
Feel free to visit my web site: https://www.jeffisaak.ca
